input: why do we suffer in life ?
what are types of sufferings in human life
responses: Dukkha is often translated as suffering. In everyday life, dukkha is most easily perceived as suffering , and that is why that translation appeals more to the imagination. Dukkha has a much broader meaning however, which threatens to be lost with suffering.

Actually dukkha or suffering could best be translated as  the friction of the wheel on the wagon-axis . We experience a similar friction during our life  journey. Things do not go as desired, whether the wheel is stationary or rolling .

Pain or suffering or dukkha can be mental as well as physical. Physical pain, for example, means something as simple as bumping your toe or maybe on a deeper level the continuous discomfort of your body which makes you move all the time.

input: what are the four noble truths ?
what are the four noble truths as per buddha ?
what are the four noble truths as told in buddhism ?
responses:
They are the truth of suffering, the truth of the cause of suffering, the truth of the end of suffering, and the truth of the path that leads to the end of suffering. More simply put, suffering exists
          it has a cause  it has an end  and it has a cause to bring about its end.

Four noble truths are The world is full of sorrow. Desire is the root cause of all sorrow. Sorrow can be conquered 
         by conquering desire. and  Desire can be conquered by following the eight fold paths  that is Ashtangirka Marga
